Award.AwardTitle: CSR:Small:Collaborative Research:An Architecture for the Emergency Re-tasking of Wireless Sensor Networks (ALERT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the development of ALERT: An Architecture for the Emergency Re-tasking of Wireless Sensor Networks. The novelty of this work lies in the theoretical foundation of re-tasking independently-deployed sensor networks, leading to a fundamental understanding of the design principles of capability reallocation and sharing to best satisfy the needs of emergency applications. Both re-tasking and integration of sensor capabilities will be transparent to the emergency applications. The resource-constrained nature of sensors, the wireless communication medium, and the failure-prone networking environment, combined with the dynamic QoS requirements of the emergency applications pose formidable challenges for the design of ALERT.
The understanding acquired from developing ALERT will promote a wider adoption of sensor network systems in support of guarding our national infrastructure and public safety. This project will result in significant scientific and technological advances that will provide invaluable help with disaster management and search-and-rescue operations. ALERT will have a broad societal impact as sensor networks are being integrated into the fabric of the society. The project will integrate research and education and will lead to the development of new graduate and undergraduate courses in sensor networks and embedded and distributed systems. In turn, these courses and their focus on information integration will introduce novel research topics to undergraduate and graduate students in computer science and engineering that fit within the overall missions of Old Dominion University and Clemson University. Focused efforts will be undertaken to stimulate interest and to facilitate the academic progress of women and underrepresented minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main focus of the project was the re-tasking of sensor networks. In its simple form, re-tasking involves changing the program that the sensors are running in a way that supports dynamic changes in the sensors' original mission.  In general, the idea of re-tasking sensors can be extended to several independently-deployed and managed sensor networks, each deployed in support of a mission. Under normal operating conditions, each of these sensor networks attends to the tasks specific to its mission.

However, when an emergency situation occurs, the original sensor networks are dissolved and a registry of sensor capabilities is drawn up. This registry is then used to establish new, short lived, sensor networks each set up in support of a task specific to the emergency handling operation.  Each of the newly created sensor networks is re-tasked on the fly. This latter task involves sending wirelessly to the various sensors in the sensor network the code that they need to execute as part of their new mission.

Once the tasks specific to emergency situation have been completed, the original sensor networks are re-established and the sensors will, once again, perform the tasks specific to their original mission.

As part of this project we have investigated several strategies and techniques for re-tasking sensor networks. The basic scenario assumed was that of an emergency situation (e.g. fire) in a certain urban area. We have also assumes that the individual first-responders deployed to the scene have the authority to re-task the sensors in their immediate vicinity. This turned out to be a very productive strategy as the first-responders were able to chart safe paths (e.g. paths that do not pass through high-temperature areas) to various buildings in the affected area.

In order to be able to re-task the sensors effectively, a number of technical issues had to be addressed. To begin, let us recall that the ad-hoc nature of sensor network deployment, location unawareness of individual sensors, their modest non-renewable energy budget, their limited computing and communication capabilities, along with the dynamically changing topology induced by the sleep-awake cycles are only a few examples of the challenges faced by the applications contemplated in the project. A considerable amount of research was conducted to develop protocols and solutions to overcome many of the aforementioned challenges. A major difficulty when using this approach is that the proposed techniques try to address each problem in isolation. As a result, protocol designers have to face the same challenges over and over again. Rather than solving each of these problems individually, facing the same challenges each time, we proposed to build on earlier work of Co-PI Olariu to construct a lightweight network backbone which provides some form of virtual infrastructure that allows the sensors to acquire coarse-grain (that is, approximate) location awareness and that promotes dynamic clustering consistent with the semantics of the specific mission.  Thus, on the one hand, the infrastructure provides the sensors with necessary information that enables them to associate their sensory data with the geographic location in which the data was measured and, on the other hand, it simplifies the task of clustering the sensors in support of various tasks. Once such an infrastructure is in place, entire protocol suites can leverage the infrastructure, resulting in ease of programming and energy savings.

Hand in hand with our main focus area, we have done pioneering work in trying to assess how the value of the information collected by the sensors decays over time. This is an important concept in time-critical emergency situations where time is of the essence.  We have formalized the problem and have obtained theoretical results that describe stochastically how the value of information decays over time and have identified three main strategies for aggregating discounted information. While we have specialized our model for aggregating time-discounted information to sensor networks, the results are perfectly general. They apply to other areas of computer science including query processing in database design, medical imaging and other application areas where time is of the essence and delayed information aggregation often results in irreversible loss. Even more broadly, our result may well impact economics where one deals with time-discounted information all the time. For example, stock information is more valuable new than old.

This project will have a broad societal impact as sensor networks are expected to be integrated into the fabric of society.  Large geographical areas will be provided with integrated sensor networks that can provide invaluable help with disaster management.  As a result of our research, independently-deployed wireless sensor networks can be integrated to use their corporate capabilities to help save both lives and property during an emergency.  The framework developed for this project can be extended to facilitate early-warning systems and automatic failover systems in the event of sensor node failure.
